stem: A 22-year-old client with Type 1 Diabetes is admitted in Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Initiation of IV insulin therapy for DKA.
Background: Blood glucose 542 mg/dL. pH 7.12. Ketones 4+.
Assessment: Client has deep, rapid breathing. Serum potassium is currently 3.1 mEq/L.
Recommendation: Stabilization of potassium BEFORE insulin bolus.

tabs.title: Metabolism & K+ Flowsheet
tabs.content:
TestResultSignificance
Serum Potassium (K+)3.1 mEq/L (Low)Critical Shift Risk
Blood Glucose542 mg/dLHyperglycemia
Anion Gap22 (High)Metabolic Acidosis

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 102/64 mmHg, HR 118 bpm, RR 28 (Kussmaul), T 98.4°F. SpO2 96%.

conditionOptions.text: DKA with Critical Hypokalemia Shift Risk

actionOptions.text: Hold the IV Insulin infusion until potassium is > 3.3 mEq/L
Administer IV Potassium supplementation as prescribed
Administer a rapid bolus of 10 Units of regular insulin immediately
Instruct the client to take deep, slow breaths to raise their pH

parameterOptions.text: Serial Serum Potassium (K+) levels and EKG for U-waves
Blood glucose and Anion Gap closure status
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is DKA with a Critical Hypokalemia Risk (c2). Insulin forces potassium from the intravascular space INTO the cells. If the patient's potassium is already low (3.1 mEq/L), starting insulin will cause it to drop to lethal levels, potentially causing cardiac arrest. Priority #1 is holding the insulin (a1) and Priority #2 is replacing the potassium (a2) first. Monitoring focus is on lab trends and EKG changes for hypokalemia (p1) and the closing of the acidotic gap (p2).
clinicalPearls: The 'Potassium Rule' in DKA: If K+ is < 3.3 mEq/L, replace potassium FIRST. If K+ is 3.3–5.3 mEq/L, replace potassium WITH insulin.
Acidosis causes potassium to leak OUT of cells (pseudo-hyperkalemia); once you fix the acidosis and add insulin, it rushes back IN.
Kussmaul breathing is a compensatory mechanism to blow off CO2 and raise pH; it should not be manually suppressed.

questionTrap.trap: Starting the insulin drip because the blood sugar is 542 mg/dL.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Blood sugar won't kill the patient in the next 10 minutes; a potassium of 2.0 mEq/L will. Always fix the 'K+' before or during the 'Sugar' fix.

mnemonic.title: K+ First
mnemonic.expansion: Potassium low? Insulin: NO. Potassium high? Insulin: HI!
